III. chco'niny against respect of persons—ii. 1-13.

(1) Courtesy to the rich, if combined with discourtesy to the poor, is a sign of weakness of faith, and proves that We are not whole-hearted in the service of Him who is the only glory of believers.—-ii. 1-4.

(2) The poor have more title to our respect than t'ne rich, since they are often rich in faith and heirs of the kingdom 3 while it is the rich who maltreat the brethren and blaspheme the name of Christ—ii. 5-7.

(3) If it is from obedience to the royal law of love that we show courtesy to the rich, it is well: but if we do this only from respect of persons, it is a breach of the law and a defiance of the lawgiver, no less than murder or adultery.—ii. 8-11.

(4) Remember that we shall all be tried by the law of liberty, which looks to the heart, and not to the outward action only. It is the merciful who obtain mercy.—ii. 12, 13.
